field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 06-2025 - Flood update #2 (2025-06-13)
field_reports.description:
Adverse Weather Alert - Yellow Level and Riverine Flood Alert - Orange Level (Caroni River) remain in effect for Trinidad until 6:00pm this afternoon (Friday 13th June 2025). The TTRCS conducted community site visits yesterday to determine the severity of the flooding in high risk and impacted communities. In many areas, the Caroni River continues to exceed capacity near the Tumpuna and El Carmen areas, and overspilling is ongoing. Water levels
remain dangerously high and forecast rainfall is expected to exacerbate current conditions. The Manuel Congo River, after an earlier decline, is now gradually rising again due to yesterday’s rainfall and is nearing critical levels once more. The South Oropouche River is also at threatening levels and continues a slow but steady rise. Some areas along this river have already experienced localized overflows, posing increased risk to surrounding communities. Further rainfall will likely worsen riverine flooding conditions. As a result, a severe risk remains to public safety, livelihoods, and property, particularly for residents in flood-prone communities along the Caroni, Manuel Congo and South Oropouche Rivers.  Other rivers, including the North Oropouche, are rising at lower rates but are
still under close observation.

Based on the latest report from the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Management, a total of 81 official reports were received which included 16 reports of street flooding, 40 reports of residential flooding, 3 damaged roofs, 12 landslides and 10 fallen trees. While the number of residential flooding is low in this report, visual observation yesterday by the TTRCS team estimates 80-100 households were directly affected with floods, where water was observed in persons homes in the areas assessed.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 06-2025 - Persistent Rainfall increases risk for major flood event
field_reports.description: Trinidad and Tobago has been under an Adverse Weather Alert since Tuesday 10th June 2025 as forecasted the passage of several tropical waves brought prolonged rain fall. On Wednesday 11th June at 6:30pm the Trinidad and Tobago Met Service issued a Riverine Flood Alert - Orange Level based on data from the national hydrological monitoring stations showed that the Caroni River would have overtopped its banks in three areas - Manuel Congo, El Carmen and Tumpuna. While weather conditions have settled over Trinidad currently, further rainfall activity will continue over the next 24 hours which will result in further elevation of these river levels. As a result, there continues to be a severe risk to public safety, livelihood and property in communities surrounding these rivers. Other major rivers, including the North and South Oropouche, are rising at relatively lower rates but are also being monitored closely. The effects on the communities in proximity to where the river has over topped is not clear at this time as no official report from state authorities has been published or shared internally with response agencies. The TTRCS will mobilize today to conduct surveillance in these areas to get a better understanding of the impact. Compiling data from trusted sources on the ground we note that several communities have experiened street and flash flooding from last night.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 11-2024 - Intense localized rainfall caused massive flash floods - Northwest Trinidad
field_reports.description: On Saturday 23rd November 2024, around 11am, local weather forecast indicated the approach of a trough system that would bring intense thunderstorm activity across much of Trinidad. Rains began falling across Trinidad on the eastern coast arond noon and the system quickly made its way across Trinidad within a couple of hours. Intense rainfall was concentrated in the northern part of the island while most of the country experienced some amount of rainfall. From 2pm initial reports came in of water levels rising in rivers in the major watercourses in Diego Martin and San Juan/Laventille and flash flooding occuring in typical places across both regions. By 3pm several watercourses began overtopping and flooding nearby street and communties. The Ministry of Rural Development at Local Government began posting notices of flooded areas and warning to avoid areas. Within the Diego Martin area the communties Carenage, Blue Basin, Morne Coco Road, Saddle Road, Maraval and Petit Valley were among the communties affected with street and flashflooding and very localized riverine flooding. A major landslide was reported on the Northcoast Road which leads to popular beaches stranding motorists on either side, and smaller landslides in hilly areas around St. James. As of this time the TTRCS does not have confirmed reports of the possible number of households affected and the extent to flooded communities.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 11-2024 - Update to flooding situation #2 (2024-11-14)
field_reports.description: There is ongoing flooding now localized to south Trinidad. Today 14th November, the TTRCS conducted on the ground assessments in the most affected areas of Penal/Debe and Woodland where flood waters are still very high in some areas making it only accessible by very high vehicles. The areas around the South Oropuche River that has burst its banks in many areas have caused localized ponding and affected homes in pockets along a wide expanse of communties. Flood waters are recedeing slowly allowing some residents to begin clean up.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 11-2024 - Adverse weather causing street and flash flooding across part of Trinidad
field_reports.description: At 10am the Trinidad and Tobago Met Services issued a Localized Flood Alert for Trinidad as ITCZ activity was forcasted to affect Trinidad today until 4pm. For much of the early morning rains have been falling and local ponding in low areas have caused some roadways especially in the more rural parts of Trinidad to be impassible as water levels reached 2 feet. Verfied images and video posted to social media confirm that the more badly affected areas incluse the Penal/Debe Regional Corporation and the Mayaro/Rio Claro Regional Corporation. Localized street flooding was also reported in the Arima Borough Corporation and Sangre Grande Regional Corporation. Some residential properties may be affected, however it may be minimal as no offical reports have been made thus far.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 08-2024 - Adverse Weather leads to flash floods in North Trinidad
field_reports.description: On 12th August 2024, the TT Met Service issued Adverse Weather Alert - Yellow Level, with predictions of gusty winds in excess of 55 km/hr and rainfall of 25 to 50 mm. This system brought intense rainrall in several parts of north Trinidad causing widespread flash floods in areas such as Port of Spain, Morvant, Eastern Main Road in the vicinity of the University of the West Indies, and the villages of Caroni and Bamboo. Water levels quickly receeded after a few hours.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Flood - 07-2024 - Ongoing flooding in South Trinidad #2 (2024-07-18)
field_reports.description: Intense rainfall associated with the passage of a Tropical Wave continued to affect the southern communities of Barrackpore, Penal Rock Road, and parts of Debe. Localized ponding in low lying areas and overtopping of some smaller tributaries are causing roadways to have several feet of water in some areas up to four feet of water. These communities are very rural and not all homes are affected. Because of perennial flooding, many homes have adapted by building on posts. The extent of the damage is not yet determined as access is only limited to high vehicles at this time. In the northern part of Trinidad today a brief, but intense shower did cause some localized flash flooding in northwest communities of Diego Martin, Maraval and Port of Spain, however this quickly subsided. TTRCS will continue to monitor the situation to determine any need for support.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2024 - Adverse Weather leads to flash floods in South Trinidad
field_reports.description: Overnight on Tuesday 16th into the early morning of Wednesday 17th, intense periods of rain fell in the southern parts of Trinidad. Several areas report street and flash flooding in areas of Penal Rock Road, Barrackpore, SS Erin Road Debe and Clarke Road, Penal. Images reported on media channels indicate several residents in these areas with one to two feet of water in their homes. Reports from the Local Government Disaster Management Unit confirms the media reports. An Adverse Weather Alert was issued for Northern Trinidad and Tobago from 10am to 4pm on Wednesday 17th July, but rains may still continue to fall in the southern part of Trinidad further exacerbating the issue. TTRCS will monitor the situation as flood waters recede to determine if any support is required from us.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Cyclone - 06-2024 - Hurricane Beryl #2 (2024-07-01)
field_reports.description:
A Hurricane Warning remains is in effect for Tobago, hurricane conditions, including sustained winds in excess of 118 km/h, within the warning area, in this case within the next 7 hours. As of 5 am, Hurricane Beryl was located near 11.7°N 59.9°W, approximately 93km northeast of Tobago, moving west near 31 km/h. Periods of showers and gusty winds have been observed and further deterioration is expected with gusts in excess of 70km/h. There is a high chance (90%) of hazardous seas with large, battering waves. Mariners should expect wave heights to increase significantly, posing a danger to small craft, coastal and offshore activities. Strong currents and choppy seas will make navigation hazardous (excerpt from Met Bulletin)

Hurricane Beryl is still impacting the Trinidad and Tobago even as the eye as passed north of Tobago. From 6am more intense weather was experienced along the north coastlines of Tobago and the northeast side of Trinidad. Tobago did experience heavy rains and wind with caused serval tress to fall in at least six communities, 27 Tobago communties are without power and as of 9am 128 people are in 14 emergency shelters across Tobago. For Trinidad the damage has been minimal, there have been some fallen trees, and power outages in six communities mainly along the northcoast area. Emergency shelters were open as a precaution, however there are no persons in shelters in Trinidad.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Cyclone - 06-2024 - Hurricane Beryl
field_reports.description: Hurricane Beryl, now a Category 3 and likely to become Category 4 as it approaches the Windward islands. Currently Tobago is under Hurricane Warning and Trinidad under Tropical Strom Watch. Beryl is expected to pass between Tobago and Barbados with adverse weather beginning from as early as 8pm on June 30th into the morning. Intense wind and rain associated with Beryl will affect Tobago more than Trinidad especially the northeastern communities of Charlottesville, and Speyside together with interior communities that suffer from landslide risk.  For Trinidad, tropical storm conditions are forecasted with less intense rainfall and winds, however we have been experiencing persistent rainfall for the last three days which have made soils saturated and rivers unable to fully run off. The additional rains will likely cause flash flooding in typical areas such as Port of Spain, and Tunapuna/Piarco. Coastal communities in the east such as Mayaro/Rio Claro could face challenges with storm surge, and north coast communities from Toco to Matelot typically suffer from fallen trees and landslides which can isolate them. Southern communities of Woodland, Penal/Debe would experience riverine floods.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Earthquake - 06-2024 - 6.2 Magnitude Earthquake
field_reports.description: At 11:58pm on June 22nd 2024 a magnitude 6.2 earthquake occured just north of Venezuela, approximatly 96km from Port of Spain. Shaking was reported by throusands across both islands and as far north as St. Vincent and as far south as Guyana. Initially the shaking caused localized power outages in northern parts of Trinidad which were quickly restored within a couple hours. Check-ins with TTRCS personnel was done over WhatsApp and there were no initial damage reports. Later on June 23rd, communications with national authorities indicated that there we no reports of damage or injuries in Trinidad or Tobago.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Other - 02-2024 - Tobago Oil Spill Incident - Canoe Bay Industrial Estate
field_reports.description:
On Wednesday 7th February 2024, at 7am reports were recieved by the Tobago Emergency Management Agency (TEMA) of the appareance of an oil-like substance washing onshore at Canoe Bay which is a remote part of the Tobago Shoreline just off the Cove Eco-Industrial Estate. That day officials of the Tobago House of Assembly (THA) and TEMA hosted a media conference indicating that an unidentified vessel had overturned about 200 meters from the costline and was eminating and oil-like substance which began to wash ashore. The THA mobilized assets and divers from its Maritime Services Unit to 1. Identify the vessel and 2. Determine if any souls were on board, the results were inconclusive as divers could not get a good view in the murky waters. However a diver was able to make out the marking "Gulfstream" on the vessel however they were not able to find the IMO vessel identifier therefore to today the vessel is still unidentified. There were no evidence that persons were onboard the vessel. In the past few days coastal clean up has been ongoing. The THA Chief Secretary and TEMA have been calling the incident a Tier 2 diaster where all national resources would be needed. Today there were reports that international assistance may be needed to help contain the situation, which would automatically make the incident an official disaster at level 3. In past major oil spill situation international assistance was needed so this is not new to have international technical assistance mobilized to support. 

A GIS representation of the affected area was done by TEMA and can be accessed here: https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=791943569640726&set=pcb.791943722974044 As the area of the overtunred vessel is solely industrial the only impact is to the environment there is not community near by. The area where the oil is coming onshore is not a tourist site not a fishing port. There may be long term damage to the coral reef at Canoe Bay which may have knock on effects with fishing areas in the vicinity. Assessments for this has not been started.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Volcanic Eruption - 01-2024 - Cascadoux Mud Volcano Eruption, Mayaro
field_reports.description: The Disaster Management Unit of the Mayaro Rio Claro Regional Corporation confirmed residents reports of a minor eruption of a mud volcano located in Cascadoux Trace, Mayaro. The area is known for the existence of several very small plumes where hot mud reaches the surface. On the night of 11th January 2024 around 11:30pm, residents in area noticed the formation of a new plume which began spewing hot mud up to 15 feet in the air. The residents contacted the Disaster Management Unit (DMU) and the DMU, Fire Service and Police Service visited the site and confirmed the report of a new plume forming and actively spewing mud. Despite the small size of the plume which was esitmated to be a few feet in diameter, can be the source of a major hazard and as a precaution three homes in close vicinity to the new plume were as to evacuate to family and neighbors away from potential danger. TTRCS will continue to monitor the situation as additional assessment of the activity will be conducted by experts today.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Flood - 12-2023 - Localized flooding and landslide
field_reports.description:
During an intense period of adverse weather which included intense heavy rainfall on the eastern coast of Tobago, incidents of one major landslide and street and flash flooding was reported. 

Area: Charlotteville, Tobago (Located on the northeastern side of the island)

Agencies involved and responding: Tobago Emergency Management Agency, Tobago Emergency Operations Centre, Community Emergency Response Team, Division of Infrastructure, Quarries and Urban Development

·        No Adverse Weather Alert from the Trinidad and Tobago Met Service.

·        More than 50 millimeters of rainfall across northeastern coastal Tobago.

·        Main road near Hairpin Bend blocked due to landslide.

·        One unoccupied residence structurally damaged (no one displaced).

·        Residents in Top River facing further impacts of landslides if the rains persisted, but this did not occur.

·        At 4:45, the TEOC had recorded five incidents, including residential and roadway flooding, landslides, blocked roads and fallen utility poles.

·        Distribution of packages with cleaning agents and other essential items was done by TEMA.

·        Clearing of blockages, tree-cutting, preliminary damage assessments started today 20/12/2023.

·        One affected homeowner noted that it was the first disaster of that magnitude that the community had ever experienced.

·        Tobago Branch Community Liaison Officer acertained from a contact in the community that not all areas were severely affected and the flooding reported in the media was isolated to only a few streets and affected only a few homes. 

TThe TTRCS will not mobilize to provide assistance in this instance, as support is being fully mobilized by the state.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2022-11 - Response Operations Update #4 (2023-01-18)
field_reports.description: TTRCS continues to respond to the immediate needs of the affected communties which are in the process of slowly recovering from the impacts of the floods. Much work was accomplished in the clean-up efforts and debirs removal which was expeditied to ensure households would have experienced a sense of comfort for the holiday period. However the damage to homes and lost household items are still being quantified by the state and less than 2% of homes affected would have received any support toward replacing lost furniture and appliances. TTRCS through other local donors would have mobilized to provide food support to the most needing households in the latter part of 2022 and additional food support at the start of 2023.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2022-11 - UPDATE - Major Flooding November 2022 #3 (2022-12-12)
field_reports.description: The Trinidad & Tobago Red Cross Society continues to respond to the devastating floods and landslides of November 26 and 27 affecting five municipalities in Trinidad. Over the last two weeks the TTRCS has mobilized fully, to bring relief to the affected population as well as begin assessments to determine the longer-term needs. During the first few days it was difficult to access communities as water levels were very high and it required specialized vehicles or boats in many instances to access the community when the TTRCS had to deliver meals. Many persons disregarded warnings to evacuate for fears of leaving their homes and possessions to criminal elements, and were trapped when water levels reached very high. Several homes also had elderly persons who had difficulty moving and felt comfortable in their homes who needed to be rescued as the water began entering their properties. By Friday 2nd December, water has receded in the majority of communities and response went into full gear to supported the affected. The TTRCS mobilized in coordination with the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Management (ODPM) and the Local Government Authorities - Disaster Management Units to bring relief with the resources we had in stock.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Flood - 2022-11 - Major Flooding 27th November 2022 #2 (2022-11-29)
field_reports.description: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society has mobilized to conduct assessments in the affected communties as a result of the widespread flooding and landslides that has ensued. With current weather patterns creating constant rainfall all communties are still heavily impacted with water as it is taking longer than expected for water to run off especially since tides are higher than usual. There are five severly impacted regions in Trinidad, Sangre Grande, Tunapuna/Piarco, Mayaro/Rio Claro, San Juan Laventille, and Penal/Debe. All of these areas (except San Juan Laventille) are experiencing over four to six feet of water and since Sunday the water levels are rising higher, especially in the western communties where the Caroni River traverses. This phenomenon is related to the movement of water from higher areas to the coastlines. The TTRCS is currently mobilizing to provide immediate relief in coordination with the national disaster office with hot meals and water to the affected areas which are marooned since Sunday. Several Shelters are open to accomodate persons who wish to evacuate, however only approximately 40 persons are in shelters. The TTRCS would have provided 250 blankets to the Ministry of Rural Development and Local Government to mobilize to shelters across Trinidad at the start of the wet season. Only when water levels subside the TTRCS will mobilize to conduct assessments at a household level.

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

field_reports.summary: TTO: Flood - 2022-11 - Major Flooding - November 26th
field_reports.description: On Friday 25th November 2022 at 6pm the Trinidad and Tobago Met Services issued a Adverse Weather Alert #1 with effect from Saturday 26th to Sunday 27th November 2022. On Saturday 27th in the early morning hours Trinidad began experiencing significant rainfall which was concentrated in the northern part of the island. Compounding weeks of constant rainfall which have caused ground level saturation and many major watercourses are already filled. Several communities along the east-west corridor began experiencing street and flash flooding. By Saturday afternoon, the Caroni River began to burst its banks in some areas causing riverine flooding in Bamboo #2, Valsayn South, Real Spring Gardens, Kelly Village, Madras Road and El Carmen, St. Helena. Into Saturday night and Sunday morning additional rainfall continued increasing the levels of water in these communities. Several roadways have been damaged as a result of undermining. On Sunday the Adverse Weather Alert Orange Level and a Riverine Flood Alert Organge Level was issued as additional rainfall was forecasted. Five major watercourses were flagged for concern including the Caroni River, North Oropouche River, South Oropouche River, the Caparo River and the Ortoire River. The TTRCS has been on the ground monitoring the high-risk communities and determining next steps. On Sunday 27th the Ministry of Education has issued a notice that all schools in Trinidad were to remain closed on Monday 28th November. Three shelters have been opened, and an emergency Cabinet Meeting was also called to plan a state-wide response.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Cyclone - 2022-10 - Adverse Weather Alert and Riverine Flood Alert - October 28th
field_reports.description: The Trinidad and Tobago Met Services issued an Adverse Weather Alert #4 Orange Level and Riverine Flood Alert #1 Orange Level on 27th October 2022. Since Tuesday 25th October, Trinidad and Tobago have been continuously impacted by heavy persistent rainfall associated with the ITCZ and the passage of several tropical waves. Ground level saturation is high creating increased run off into rivers and streams. On a daily basis there has been flash flooding reported in the urban areas since Tuesday. As the major water courses increase in capacity there is greater risk of communities being affected. As of 7am parts of the Caroni River are showing signs of overtopping in typical areas, however mitigation measures such as elevated levees and retention ponds are preventing direct community impact. Many roadways in the southern part of the island near river and stream crossings are becoming impassable as water levels rise in these areas. The Ministry of Education has proactively closed schools today on both islands as a precaution. Isolated reports of homes being impacted due to flood waters are being received, but these are in typical areas that usually experience floods on a regular basis. The TTRCS will continue to monitor the situation as more intense rainfall is forecasted to today into the weekend.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Cyclone - 2022-10 - Invest 91L currently impacting Trinidad and Tobago
field_reports.description: On 04/10/2022, the Trinidad and Tobago Met Services issued a Yellow Alert for potential hazardous weather related to Invest 91L. The TTRCS participated in a NEOC meeting hosted by the ODPM on 04/10/2022 at 2pm to share operational priorities and strategy to prepare for impact. As on 05/10/2022, 4am, the Eastern end of Tobago and the east coast of Trinidad began experiencing squally weather. Throughout the morning TTRCS has been monitoring the impacts of the system as it traverses the island. As of 10am we have been receving reports of many communities in the eastern part of the island such as Arouca, Arima, Tunapuna, Sangre Grande, Piarco and St. Helena experiencing heavy flash flooding as a result of small roadside drains and outfalls overtopping their banks. This is causing water to spill out onto roadways and into homes. Part of the Churchhill Roosevelt Highway heading east from Trinicity is impassible as there is about 12inches of water on the highway. TTRCS will continue to monitor as the system passes to determine the applicable response as flood waters receede.

field_reports.summary: TTO: Cyclone - 2022-09 - Preparations for Adverse Weather - Invest 98L
field_reports.description: The TT Met Office issued Adverse Weather Alert 1 - Yellow Level for hazardous weather starting 21/09/2022 at 5am and continuing until Thursday 8pm. We are expected to experience gusty winds in excess of 70km/h and up to 125mm of rainfall. The TTRCS participated in the ODPM NEOC Briefing today at 3:30pm where all stakeholders reiterated their preparedness levels. The TTRCS maintained a heightened preparedness level since the start of the hurricane season and continue to operate in anticipate of impact as several active tropical waves impact the islands and a weekly basis. After the ODPM Briefing, the TTRCS staff were put on alert as to potential impact scenarios and we stand ready to mobilize in the event of any major impacts. We have also communicated with the Ministry of Rural Development and Local Government re: gaps and none were identified. Our support is usually channeled through Local Government. TTRCS currently maintains a stock of 200 tarpaulins, 200 Blankets, 200 Cleaning Kits, 200 Hygiene Kits, and 200 kitchen sets. We will continue to monitor the situation provide updates as needed.

field_reports.affected_pop_centres: Tunapuna, Piarco, Caroni, St. Helena, Kelly Village
field_reports.summary: TTO: Flood - 2022-08 - Potential Riverine Floods in Trinidad
field_reports.description: On Thursday 4th August 2022 at 5:00pm the Trinidad and Tobago Met Office issued a Riverine Flood Alert for Trinidad at a Yellow Alert Stage. For several days Trinidad and Tobago have been experiencing significant amounts of rainfall due to the passage of several tropical waves back to back. Water courses across the country are not getting an opportunity to drain out to sea due the amount of rainfall. Our major river, the Caroni River has been at threshold levels for some days. On Thursday afternoon there were reports that at one point along the Caroni River, farmers cut the embankment for access to water for farms and at this point, the river began to overtop its banks and was slowly flooding some streets within the Caroni community which was located approximately 1000 feet from the river bank. At 9pm approximately six residents in the area reported flood waters entering their property and homes. The Municipality deployed a vehicle with three small water pumps, which were not able to displace enough water. Around 2am on Friday 5th August, the Ministry of Work deployed a trailer mounter 12" pump which was able to slow the water from entering further in to the community, until more rains began to fall during the early morning hours. At 10pm we received media reports of several streets in Caroni being flooded with 6-8 inches of water as well as some homes having about 1 foot of water. Reports from the Disaster Management Unit indicate that there are about 30 possible homes that may have been affected, but detailed assessments are still underway. The Met Office has since discontinued the Riverine Flood Alert as waters begin to recede from all areas.

field_reports.affected_pop_centres: Sangre Grande, Tunapuna/Piarco, Diego Martin, Maraval, Port of Spain, Penal, Debe, Chaguanas
field_reports.summary: TTO: Cyclone - 2022-06 - Preparation Actions related to Invest 94L
field_reports.description: Invest 94L has been increased to a 70% chance of tropical cyclone formation over the next five days according to the NOAA NHC. The Trinidad and Tobago Met Office has issued Official Statement #1, today Sunday 26th June 2022 which indicates that Trinidad and Tobago will experience adverse weather from Tuesday night regardless if Invest 94L develops in to a Topical Cyclone (TD or TS) or not. As Tropical Wave 11 is currently impacting T&T today (26/06/2022) and the potential of intense rainfall from Invest 94L Tuesday in to Wednesday and another tropical wave impacting T&T on Friday 1st July, the potential for riverine flooding is significant.

results.name: TTO: Cyclone - 2022-06 - Preparation Actions related to Invest 94L

results.summary: From 30/06/2021 to 01/07/2021, a Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 93 km/h) FIVE-21 was active in Atlantic. The cyclone affects these countries: Barbados, Trinidad and Tobago, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Martinique, Grenada, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Cuba, United States, Jamaica (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.
